title: Anorectal Malformation
diagnosis_topic: Imperforate anus with fistula requiring staged repair
setup_script: “A newborn boy has no visible anal opening. He has not passed stool but voids normally. The abdomen is distended and meconium appears at the urethral meatus. How would you proceed?”

dynamic_flow.reply: Absence of anal opening; meconium noted at urethral meatus suggesting rectourethral fistula.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident orders cross-table prone lateral X-ray at 24 hours
dynamic_flow.reply: Determines distance between rectal pouch and perineal skin (high vs. low lesion).

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident evaluates for associated anomalies
dynamic_flow.reply: Renal ultrasound, echocardiogram, and spinal ultrasound obtained to look for VACTERL association.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident keeps patient NPO and places replogle tube for gastric decompression
dynamic_flow.reply: Abdominal distension improves; risk of aspiration decreases.
High malformation — diverting colostomy with mucous fistula followed by posterior sagittal anorectoplasty (PSARP) at 3–6 months; low malformation — primary perineal anoplasty soon after birth.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident counsels parents on colostomy care
dynamic_flow.reply: Parents demonstrate understanding of stoma care and potential complications.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident delays creation of colostomy in high lesion
dynamic_flow.reply: Patient develops abdominal distension, perforation risk, and possible sepsis.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident addresses urinary tract evaluation
dynamic_flow.reply: Voiding cystourethrogram shows rectourethral fistula; renal function intact.
Constipation, soiling, and strictures are discussed; requires bowel management program and dilatations.
Urology, nephrology, gastroenterology, and physical therapy become involved in care plan.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident provides long-term follow-up plan
dynamic_flow.reply: Continence assessments are scheduled throughout childhood with psychosocial support.

critical_decision_points: Identification of anorectal malformation and associated fistula
Staged surgical management based on lesion level
Parental education on colostomy care and postoperative expectations
Long-term bowel management and multidisciplinary follow-up
